data.title: Visit California
data.meta_description: Relax by the pool, hike to a leafy palm oasis, soak in a soothing spa, or soar in a balloon above this chic desert hideaway
data.text:
Fed by a deep underground aquifer, the desert in Greater Palm Springs gushes to life in regal palm groves and fabulous swimming pools, and also in a string of vibrant communitiesâPalm Desert, Rancho Mirage, Indian Wells, La Quinta, Coachella, Desert Hot Springs, and the namesake town of Palm Springs. This is where 1950s celebrities like Frank Sinatra and Elvis Presley built sleek estates, played golf at championship courses, and wined and dined the desert night away.

Things to Do in Palm Springs

Today, the Coachella Valley still sports a cool, mid-century modern vibe, but a new wave of entrepreneurs has brought in cutting-edge dining and shopping. Stroll through the Palm Springs Art Museumâs mix of contemporary and modern paintings, sculpture, and art glass. Visit Moortenâs Botanical Garden, a family-owned cactarium planted with 3,000-plus specimens. For brunch or dinner, take your pick from Palm Springsâ primo restaurantsâthe ever-evolving food scene offers countless choices.

Exploring the Outdoors in Palm Springs

And of course, the beauty of the California desert is everywhere you look. Take a hike in the Indian Canyons, where streams tumble down from the San Jacinto Mountains, dense palm groves provide year-round shade, and bighorn sheep clatter across the hillsides. Located on tribal land on Palm Springsâ southwest edge, each of the Indian Canyons has its own distinct character. Closest to downtown is Tahquitz Canyon, where you can join a guided walk or hike on your own to see a perennial 60-foot waterfall. (Movie buffs may recognize these falls as the entrance to Shangri-la in Frank Capra's 1937 film classic Lost Horizon.) The Tahquitz visitor center highlights the regionâs Native American culture with a film and exhibits.

Nearby Palm and Andreas Canyons are laced with footpaths leading past colorful rock formations to streamside palm oases and Indian rock art. Take an easy stroll through Andreas Canyon to watch hummingbirds flit among more than 150 species of plants. Or try to keep your feet dry as you crisscross Murray Canyonâs creek on a twisting 2-mile trail. You can never guess whatâs coming around the bend in this labyrinthine canyonâsoaring red cliffs, stately fan palms, and barrel cactus that swell after spring rains. At trailâs end, you reach the Seven Sisters, a terraced waterfall that drops over slick granite.

Ride a Hot-Air Balloon in Palm Springs

To get a wide-angle perspective on this soulful landscape, take a hot-air balloon ride with tour operators like Fantasy Balloon Flights, Balloons Above, and HavNFun Hot Air Balloons. As you float 1,000 feet above the desert floor, your FAA-certified pilot will point out landmarks like the San Andreas Fault, the Salton Sea, and even the homes of Hollywood celebrities. When you get back down to earth, salute your adventure with a champagne toast.

Where to Relax and Stay in Palm Springs

Prefer to soak instead of soar? Take this sand-and-sky desert oasis and add natural thermal mineral water, and you have a hot spot for luxurious spas. Southeast of Palm Springs, the 38,000-square-foot spa at Marriott Desert Springs Resort & Spa is a wonderland of spoil-me services with dozens of private treatment rooms, a salon, fitness facility, and soothing saltwater pool. Spa guests can take advantage of hot and cold plunge pools plus ancient Ayurvedic healing treatments.

For a more intimate experience, consider Agua Serena spa (Spanish for âpeaceful watersâ) at Hyatt Regency Indian Wells Resort & Spa. Before or after your massage, lounge beside a dipping pool with relaxing fountains and swaying palm trees. Or go luxe at Desert Hot Springs: Two Bunch Palms, the A-listersâ getaway where palm-shaded pools brim with silky water, offers an incredible variety of treatments, from water shiatsu to mud baths to sound vibration therapy.

About a 20-minute drive away in Cabazon is Morongo Casino Resort & Spa; even if you do not take advantage of their exceptional lodging options, you can purchase a day pass to relax and enjoy the enormous pool, or pay a little extra for deluxe experiences like a beach experience, a âlazy riverâ innertube float, or even a nighttime pool party complete with a DJ.

Fans of The Rat Pack can spend an evening taking in top-notch live entertainmentâmuch of it jazz or popular music from the 1950s and 60sâat the Purple Room Palm Springs, the same venue that often hosted that famous crew. Originally opened in 1960, the club went dark in the early aughts but was reopened with much fanfare in 2013.
